history.content:
For industry I think the more "software" side classes are the most useful (even though they may not be as mathy/problem solving oriented). So stuff like:

CS 162 Operating System

CS 161 Security

CS 186 Databases

CS 160 User Interfaces

CS 168 Internet Protocols

CS 164 Languages and Compilers

CS 169 Software Engineering

Though I wouldn't consider it an "industry-oriented" course, many students also think CS 170 (Algorithms) is useful for getting practice with algorithms, which are good to know for programming interviews. But you should only take CS 170 if you really want to learn about interesting algorithms and CS Theory, if your goal is just to pass interviews then doing lots of Leetcode/Hackerrank is probably more worth your time (ex. Leetcode DeCal).

For industry I think the more "software" side classes are the most useful (even though they may not be as mathy/problem solving oriented). So stuff like:

CS 162 Operating System

CS 161 Security

CS 186 Databases

CS 160 User Interfaces

CS 168 Internet Protocols

CS 164 Languages and Compilers

CS 169 Software Engineering

Though I wouldn't consider it an "industry-oriented" course, many students also think CS 170 (Algorithms) is useful for getting practice with algorithms, which are good to know for programing interviews. But you should only take CS 170 if you really want to learn about interesting algorithms and CS Theory, if your goal is just to pass interviews then doing lots of Leetcode/Hackerrank is probably more worth your time.

For industry I think the more "software" side classes are the most useful (even though they may not be as mathy/problem solving oriented). So stuff like:

CS 162 Operating System

CS 161 Security

CS 186 Databases

CS 160 User Interfaces

CS 168 Internet Protocols

CS 164 Languages and Compilers

CS 169 Software Engineering

Though I wouldn't consider it an "industry-oriented" course, many students also think CS 170 (Algorithms) is useful for getting practice with algorithms, which are good to know for programing interviews. But you should only take CS 170 if you really want to learn about interesting algorithms and CS Theory, if your goal is just to pass interviews then doing lots of Leetcode/Hackerrank is probably a better bet.
What upper div courses you think are very helpful for who is interested in being a software engineer?
history.subject: upper div courses guidline
